*[Bug 18988] Unifying similar messages for translation*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18988>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1
                 CC|                            |maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch

--- Comment #1 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Thank you, Michael, for addressing this message translation issue more
systematically.
I had myself done such unifications on a small scale basis, almost always when
some part of the *code* was changed additionally.

However, I think you (as native English speaker, even though almost surely of
Italian descent from your last name) are overlooking something (s.below);
in addition to that, I guess many (me included) would prefer being less
"thorough" and favor simple source code, more.

Notably, this change, replacing
```
 stop("invalid 'dims'")
```
by
```
 stop(gettextf("invalid '%s'", "dims"), domain=NA)
```
seems to be too much "code bloat".  Translators really can globally replace
"invalid" by the correct word in their language, very quickly.

But I think there is one crucial oversight here: probably in quite a few
languages (notably western European ones I "kind of" know), the translators
additionally must adapt the adjective to the correct gender and plural/singular
form, hence the ending (in the above cases) needs to be adapted in any case by
the translator.
Even in the above example (where 'dims' is an argument name), one could argue
that the adjective should reflect the plural, and indeed, e.g., currently, 
`src/library/base/po/R-es.po` has
```
msgid "invalid 'dims'"
msgstr "'dims' no válidas"
```
(the (LaTeX) v\'alidas  with 1 unicode character is not properly rendered in
our bugzilla..)
using female plural "as" (matching Spanish "dimensi'ones" f, pl 
  [ 'o : our bugzilla doesn't render unicode accented characters correctly..])
Similarly for (almost?) all the half dozen languages I know well enough to know
they use such endings.

Even though I'm grateful for your proposal, according to the above, I think
your patch would need to become considerably smaller, before we'dconsider
applying it.

text:
*[Bug 18988] Unifying similar messages for translation*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18988>

Mikael Jagan (<mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |jaganmn@mcmaster.ca

--- Comment #2 from Mikael Jagan (<mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>) ---
(In reply to Martin Maechler from comment #1)
When dealing with symbols, like `dims` in `gettext("invalid 'dims'")` or
`gettextf("invalid '%s'", "dims")`, I think that code authors could simplify
the work of translators by writing, e.g., `gettextf("invalid argument '%s'",
"dims")`, leading unambiguously to a singular declension of the adjective
"invalid".  That seems appropriate, too, because if `typeof(dims)` is invalid,
then it is really the singular object-as-a-whole that is invalid, rather than
some set of component "dimensions".  The plural declension seems misleading in
this case.

When dealing with calls, like `nrow(x)` in `gettext("invalid nrow(x)")` or
`gettextf("invalid %s", "nrow(x)")`, I would agree that the former is often
better for translation, because the noun being modified by "invalid" is implied
by the function name ("number" in "number of rows").  I guess that code authors
can avoid some repetition with `gettextf("invalid nrow(%s)", "x")`, since it is
sufficient that translators have the name of the outermost function, but then I
am sympathetic to Martin's comment about thoroughness at the cost of
compactness.

text:
*[Bug 18987] Report server-side errors in package downloads using X-Error-Message header*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18987>

Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |simon.urbanek@r-project.org

--- Comment #1 from Simon Urbanek (<mailto:simon.urbanek@r-project.org|simon.urbanek@r-project.org>) ---
Julian, thanks! I can see the intention, but `X-Error-Message` is not part of
any standard and AFAICT is discouraged in favour of information provided in the
response body which is way more commonly used (either free-form or RFC9457 for
structure responses). Hence is it not clear that this is worth the effort for
something as rare as `X-Error-Message`, but may make more sense for body
responses. In order to understand the use-cases better, it would be great to
see real endpoints and usage here.
